evidence.pdf_reference: Photocatalytic reduction of carbon dioxide (CO 2 ) into valuable hydrocarbon such as methane (CH 4 ) using water as reducing agent is a good strategy for environment and energy applications.In this study, a facile and simple sol-gel method was employed for the synthesis of metal (Cu and Ag) loaded nanosized NTiO 2 photocatalyst.The prepared photocatalysts were characterized by X-ray diffraction, transmission electron microscopy, BET Surface area analyzer, X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy and UV-vis

in methane production.The present study results show that the Ag-NTiO 2 photocatalyst was stable under the present experimental conditions even after 6 h irradiation time. In the general reaction mechanism for CO 2 photoreduction over the photocatalyst, it can be proposed that the photocatalyst was excited by light irradiation to generate electrons (at the conduction band) and holes (at the valence band).The produced holes reacted with the adsorbed H 2 O molecules to form H ions, the H ions then reacted

spectroscopy and UV-vis diffuses reflectance spectroscopy.The photocatalytic conversion of CO 2 into methane was carried out under visible light irradiation (420 nm) by prepared photocatalysts in order to evaluate the photocatalytic efficiency.The results demonstrate that Ag loaded NTiO 2 showed enhanced photocatalytic performance for methane production from CO 2 compared to other Cu-NTiO 2 , NTiO 2 and TiO 2 photocatalysts.The improvement in the photocatalytic activity could be attributed to high specific

of mixed energy levels between the valence band and conduction band of TiO 2 , thus enhanced visible light absorption of the catalyst. In this study, the photocatalytic performance of metal ions (Cu and Ag) loaded and nitrogen doped TiO 2 nanoparticles for the photoreduction of CO 2 under visible light irradiation (420 nm) was investigated and results are shown in Fig. 6A.During the photocatalysis reaction, the methane was the only hydrocarbon product detected in the gas phase over all the prepared

transfer of electrons from the conduction band of TiO 2 to metallic silver particles is possible, which played its major role to enhance the photocatalytic activity of Ag-N TiO 2 under visible light irradiation.In addition, the residual silver ions present within the material, acting as efficient electron traps to enhance the photocatalytic performance. conduction under visible light irradiation.Secondly, the separation and transportation of photocreated electrons and holes is crucial for photocatalytic activity.The silver particles in the co-doped sample acted as electron-hole separation centres due to deposition onto the surface of TiO 2 .It can be ascribed to the reason that radius of Ag ions (126 pm) is much larger than that of Ti 4 (68 pm) and so the Ag ions introduced by the sol-gel process would not enter into the lattice of anatase phase of TiO 2

in methane production.The present study results show that the Ag-NTiO 2 photocatalyst was stable under the present experimental conditions even after 6 h irradiation time. In the general reaction mechanism for CO 2 photoreduction over the photocatalyst, it can be proposed that the photocatalyst was excited by light irradiation to generate electrons (at the conduction band) and holes (at the valence band).The produced holes reacted with the adsorbed H 2 O molecules to form H ions, the H ions then reacted

H ions, the H ions then reacted with electrons to form H radicals.After this, CO 2 was reduced by H radicals to produce methane 6,33,42.The excellent performance of the prepared photocatalyst (Ag-NTiO 2 ) can be explained by the following mechanism (shown in Scheme 1).The doped nitrogen into TiO 2 lattice created a new N2p state slightly above the valence band top which consists of O2p state.Therefore, the electrons were excited from the highest occupied N2p state to the conduction under visible light
